Fig. 1 Influence of pH on the synthesis of CP-MS41 (6.0): (a) pH 10.9, (b) pH 11.1, (c) pH 11.29, (d) pH 11.34, (e) pH 11.43 and (f) pH 11.5 (pH of (c)–(e) were adjusted with 35% HCl; reproducibility±0.02 pH). Fig. 2 N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of host and immobilized materials (filled symbol for desorption and open symbol for adsorption): (a) n-EImBr-MS41 (4.5) and (b) CP-MS41 (4.5). Fig. 3 Pore size distribution for host and immobilized materials: (a) n-EImBr-MS41 (4.5) and (b) CP-MS41 (4.5). Fig. 4 CP 13C MAS NMR spectra of n-EImBr-MS41 molecular sieves. Fig. 5 29Si MAS NMR spectra of (a) parent CP-MS41 (4.5) and (b) n-EImBr-MS41 (4.5) molecular sieves. Fig. 6 FT-IR spectra of host and immobilized MS41 (4.5) molecular sieves: (a) n-EImBr-MS41, (b) iso-PImBr-MS41, (c) n-PImBr-MS41, (d) n-BImBr-MS41 and (e) CP-MS41. Fig. 7 Enhanced FT-IR spectra of C–N stretch for both host and immobilized MS41 (4.5) molecular sieves: (a) n-EImBr-MS41, (b) iso-PImBr-MS41, (c) n-PImBr-MS41, (d) n-BImBr-MS41 and (e) CP-MS41. Scheme 1 Schematic diagram for immobilization of imidazolium salt on the hybrid MS41 materials. Scheme 2 General formation reaction of cyclic carbonate from carbon dioxide and oxirane. Scheme 3 The mechanism for the formation of carbonates through the cyclic intermediate using immobilized ionic liquids (IILs). Functionalization of organic ions on hybrid MCM-41 for cycloaddition reaction: The effective conversion of carbon dioxide Seshachalam Udayakumar ⁎ Mi-Kyung Lee Hye-Lim Shim Dae-Won Park Division of Chemical Engineering, Pusan National University, San 30, Jangjun-dong, Kumjung-gu, Busan 609-735, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 10 5636 7301; fax: +82 51 512 8563. Graphical abstract The surface activity of MS41 was modified through consecutive immobilization of imidazole, followed by alkylation with an alkyl halide, resulting in the imidazole substituent-immobilized MS41 (RIm+X−-MS41 or IIL). A wide variety of CP-MS41 and RIm+X−-MS41 were synthesized and characterized by various physico-chemical techniques. Activation of chloropropyl MCM-41 (CP-MS41) and its utilization in the synthesis of allyl glycidyl carbonate over functionalized mesoporous MS41 solids has been investigated. The surface activity of MS41 was modified through consecutive immobilization of imidazole, followed by alkylation with an alkyl halide, resulting in the imidazole substituent-immobilized MS41 (RIm+X−-MS41 or IIL). A wide variety of CP-MS41 and RIm+X−-MS41 were synthesized and characterized using XRD, BET, elemental analysis (EA), SEM, CP13C, 29Si MAS-NMR, and FT-IR. EA and FT-IR confirmed adduct formation of ionic liquids with the chloropropyl groups on the host system. The efficiency of immobilization of activated materials was investigated by FT-IR and EA. RIm+X−-MS41 reacted further with oxiranes adsorbed on solid ions, forming cyclic carbonates. The IIL with a lower alkyl chain length and high electron-donating tendencies showed a higher level of reusability and superior activity. The CP-MS41 functionalized with isopropyl imidazolium bromide (iso-PImBr-MS41) exhibited the highest turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF). Keywords CO2 utilization Ionic liquid functionalization Eco-friendly processes Hybrid MS41 1 Introduction Greater utilization of CO2 as a renewable raw material in the chemical industry is an area of current interest. At present, CO2 is used in the manufacture of urea, salicylic and para-hydroxy benzoic acids, methanol, and cyclic carbonates. In particular, tremendous interest centers on the synthesis of cyclic carbonates, due to a wide variety of applications in the production of electrolyte components in lithium batteries, aprotic polar solvents, chemical intermediates, and monomers in the production of pharmaceutical and fine chemicals [1–8]. Its increased use is feasible only if this thermodynamically stable and kinetically inert molecule can be activated for reaction. Although many phosgene-free processes for the synthesis of corresponding five-membered cyclic carbonates have been reported [9–14], the reaction of epoxides with carbon dioxide has also attracted considerable attention. In the last decade of the 20th century, many catalytic systems [15–20] were developed for the insertion of carbon dioxide into oxiranes, these included alkali metal salts [21], alkali metal salts combined with crown ethers or quaternary ammonium salts [22], organoantimony halides [23], MgO [24] or Mg–Al mixed oxides [25], ionic liquids [26–31], porphyrins [32], transition-metal complexes [33–44], phenol- and organic-based or sodium iodide [45,46], phthalocyanine [47], polyoxometalate [48], supercritical carbon dioxide [49], amorphous silica immobilized ionic liquid/ZnCl2 [50], amine-functionalized mesoporous Ti(Al)-SBA-15 [51], and as-made MCM-41 [52]. However, these catalysts suffer from low catalytic activity and/or selectivity, low stability, separation, and require high pressure and/or high temperatures. Hence, the development of a highly efficient solid catalyst system for the chemical fixation of carbon dioxide under mild conditions remains a challenge. The well-ordered mesoporous solids opened a new research trend in advanced materials due to their large pore size and high accessibility that reduces the traffic inside the pores for reactants as well as products. The functionalization of these materials by post-grafting techniques increases the efficiency for utilization of large pore materials, though those methods show some uncertainty for generation of functionality with MS41 systems due to non-uniform distributions of functionalities, more amorphousness, and self-polymerization. Recently, a new synthetic approach has been reported for the preparation of hybrid inorganic–organic mesoporous materials based on the co-condensation of siloxane and organosiloxane precursors in the presence of a templating surfactant solution [53–58]. These materials are of particular interest on account of their regular, ordered architecture; the materials allow high accessibility of the immobilized ionic liquid units due to the ionic liquid being ionically connected to the surface of supported materials through an appropriate linker. The use of ionic liquids as environmentally benign media for catalytic processes or chemical extraction has received much interest during the last few years as they possess some important features, such as negligible vapor pressure, unique solvation properties, and good ion conductivity, catalytic activity, and selectivity [59–63]. Many reactions catalyzed with ionic liquids that show high performance have been reported [64]. These ionic liquids have both anionic and cationic counter parts, which can be tuned for specific purposes; however, the major problem associated with most homogenous catalyst systems is the need for separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture and recycling of the catalyst [65]. The anchoring of the ionic liquid units tends to force the active sites towards the center of the pores, which imparts high chemical and thermal stability, leading to high catalytic activity. In this study, we prepared the immobilized ionic liquid (IIL) by a two-step immobilization on CP-MS41. A better ionization and uniform distribution of IL over a CP-MS41 system for the effective utilization of CO2 is one of our main objectives. These open-type active sites containing a catalyst were very efficient in chemical fixation of carbon dioxide to allyl glycidyl ether to produce the five-membered cyclic carbonate under mild reaction conditions with high TON and TOF in the absence of solvents. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of hybrid material, method of solvent extraction, and immobilization 2.1.1 One-pot synthesis method of CP-MS41 (x) The CP-MS41s (x =4.5, 6.0, 7.5, and 9.0) were synthesized according to the previously reported method [66], using tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, Aldrich) as a silicon source, 3-chloropropyltriethoxysilane (ClPTES, Aldrich) as an organosilane source, and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTMABr, Lancaster) as a template. Tetramethylammonium hydroxide (25% aqueous TMAOH, Aldrich) was used to make the reaction alkaline. The molar ratio of the organically modified MCM-41 materials was determined from the various constituents in the synthesis mixture as follows: (1+ X) TEOS:(0.222− X) ClPTES:0.29 C16TMABr:0.58 TMA-OH:81.67 H2O; where the (1+ X)/(0.222− X) ratio ranged from 4.5 to 9.0, (1+ X) ranged from 1000 to 1100 and (X) was 0.00 (4.5), 0.048 (6.0), 0.078 (7.5), or 0.100 (9.0). Solution A: In a typical synthesis, TEOS [19.45mL (4.5), 20.36mL (6.0), 20.96mL (7.5) and 21.39mL (9.0)] was mixed with ClPTES [4.84mL (4.5), 3.81mL (6.0), 3.14mL (7.5) and 2.66mL (9.0)]. Solution A was added to Solution B, which consisted of 18.35g of TMA-OH and 18.0g of H2O. The mixture was stirred for 5min with the resulting solution denoted as Solution C. Solution D contained 9.1g of CTMABr dissolved in a mixture of 30.0g H2O and 45.0mL EtOH. Solution C was added into Solution D and the mixture was stirred vigorously at room temperature for 45min. The mixture was then heated in a water bath at 80°C for 45min to remove the alcohol added and produced from alkoxide hydrolysis. Finally, 54.0g H2O was added slowly to the solution during which the clear liquid turned into a turbid gel. The gel was aged overnight with continuous stirring for 20h (pH∼12.1), and the resulting pH of the gel was adjusted to 11.3 with 4.0N HCl. The final solution was stirred for 4h, and the resulting gel was heated in a Teflon-coated, stainless-steel autoclave at 140°C for 48h. 2.1.2 Solvent extraction of as-made CP-MS41 The surfactant was extracted from 1.5g of the as-synthesized hybrid material with 210.0mL ethanol and 6.0mL 35% HCl at 65°C for 6h for the first extraction. In the second extraction, 1.5g of the as-synthesized hybrid material was extracted with 210.0mL of ethanol and 20.0mL of 35% HCl at 65°C for 24h [67]. The resulting solid was then filtered, washed sequentially with 500.0mL ethanol and 2.0L of distilled water, and dried in air at 100°C. The same procedure was repeated to ensure maximum extraction. 2.1.3 Synthesis of RIm+X−-MS41 from hybrid MS41 The solvents were dried using standard procedures (benzene dried overnight over CaCl2), distilled under N2, and kept over 5Å molecular sieves. The immobilization experiments were carried out using standard Schlenk techniques under a nitrogen atmosphere (99.99%) applying the following procedure. The CP-MS41 (4.5) was pre-activated at 200°C under vacuum (0.1Pa) for 4h to remove the physisorbed water. Five grams of mesoporous molecular sieves were immobilized with imidazole (5.0mmol/g) and dry benzene (10.0mL/g) refluxing at 90°C under a nitrogen atmosphere. Alkyl halide (10.0mmol/g) was then added and the resulting mixture stirred for 12h. The excess imidazole and alkyl halide were removed by filtration, followed by repeated washing with 2.0L dichloromethane (2.0L/5.0g of catalyst). The resulting solid was dried under vacuum at room temperature. The IILs (Scheme 1 ) were prepared from the following: (1-bromoethane) 1BE; (2-bromopropane) 2BP; (1-bromopropane) 1BP and (1-bromobutane) 1BB on CP-MS41 designated as n-EImBr-MS41 (1-propyl-3-n-ethylimidazolium bromide-MS41); iso-PImBr-MS41 (1-propyl-3-iso-propylimidazolium bromide-MS41); n-PImBr-MS41 (1-propyl-3-n-propylimidazolium bromide-MS41); and n-BImBr-MS41 (1-propyl-3-n-butylimidazolium bromide-MS41). 2.2 Sample characterization The high-resolution powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the solvent-extracted CP-MS41 (TEOS/ClPTES=4.5, 6.0, 7.5 and 9.0) molecular sieves were obtained using a Philips diffractometer (X’pert PRO MPD) with nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation and a liquid nitrogen cooled germanium solid-state detector. The XRD patterns were recorded between 1.3° and 11° 2θ in steps of 0.005°. The surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution were measured by nitrogen adsorption at 77K using an ASAP2010 poromentry system from Micromeritics Corporation Noreross, GA. The solvent-extracted samples were degassed at 110°C and 10−3 Pa overnight before the adsorption experiments. The mesopore volume was estimated from the amount of nitrogen adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.5 by assuming that all the mesopores were filled with condensed nitrogen in the normal liquid state. The pore size distribution was estimated using the Barrett, Joyner and Halenda (BJH) algorithm (ASAP2010) built-in software from Micromeritics. The mid-infrared (IR) spectra of the solvent-extracted CP-MS41 and IILs were collected on a Nicolet (Avatar 360) instrument using a KBr pellet technique, whereby 10.0mg of the sample was ground with approximately 200.0mg of spectral grade KBr to form a pellet under hydraulic pressure to record the IR spectrum in the 4000–400cm−1 range. The 29Si, 13C, and 1H solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) experiments were carried out at frequencies of 79.5, 100.6, and 400.2MHz, respectively, on an INOVA-400WB spectrometer equipped with a commercial 4.0mm T3 HXY MAS probe. All the NMR spectra were measured at room temperature under the following conditions: magic-angle spinning at 5.0kHz; π/2 pulse, 6.5μs, and a repetition delay of 60s; 3928 scans. All NMR spectra were referenced to tetramethylsilane. The 13C{1H} cross-polarization spectra were measured with a recycle delay of 5.0s, 1024 scans. The CP contact times were 1.5μs under the following conditions: magic-angle spinning at 5.0kHz; π/2 pulse, 7.0μs. Elemental analysis was performed using Vario EL III whereby 2.0mg of the sample was subjected to 1100°C, while sulfanilic acid was used as a standard. 2.3 Catalytic runs The syntheses of allyl glycidyl carbonate (AGC or 4-[(prop-2-en-1-yloxy)methyl]-1,3-dioxolan-2-one) from allyl glycidyl ether (AGE or 2-[(prop-2-en-1-yloxy)methyl]oxirane) and CO2 using RIm+X−-MS41s were carried out under a CO2 atmosphere at a pressure of 0.86–2.58MPa (Scheme 2 ) in a high pressure reactor (55.0mL). The catalyst was introduced into the high-pressure reactor containing 40.0mmol of AGE with and without the solvent with 0.5 or 1.0g of the catalyst (amount of the catalyst based on the amine content) under 0.86–2.58MPa of CO2 at 80–140°C for 6h. A small portion of the reaction mixture was used to analyze the AGC concentration using a gas chromatograph (HP 6890 A) equipped with a HP-1 capillary column. The five-membered cyclic carbonate was confirmed using a standard sample. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization Fig. 1(c–e) shows the effect of pH on the synthesis of CP-MS41 (6.0). They show that the solvent extraction of CP-MS41 (6.0) produced a hexagonal mesophase with the typical intense diffraction pattern of the (100) plane [68–73]. The presence of high angle peaks corresponding to (110), (200), and (210) planes confirmed that the mesoporous materials possess a well-defined pore structure, also confirming that the materials were unaffected by the acid treatment. However, CP-MS41 exists a very narrow operation range of pH between 11.29 (c) and 11.43 (e). Lower and higher pHs did not produce a well-ordered hexagonal mesophase; in order to ensure accuracy, we adjusted the pH to 11.3 for future studies. Table 1 shows the d 100 spacing and lattice parameter (a 0) of the four CP-MS41 of different ratios of TEOS-to-ClPTES [66]. The crystallinity of the materials increased (I 100 from Table 1) with an increasing TEOS to ClPTES ratio. However, the I 100 peak increased drastically with increasing TEOS-to-ClPTES ratio from 4.5 to 6.0. Fig. 2 and Table 1 show the adsorption–desorption isotherms of n-EImBr activated MS41 and CP-MS41. n-EImBr-MS41 shows much lower surface area (for host 614m2/g and for IILs 459m2/g) and much lower total pore volume (for host 0.66cm3/g and for IILs 0.27cm3/g) than those of CP-MS41. Fig. 3 shows that n-EImBr-MS41 has smaller average pore diameter calculated from BJH method (for host 22.4Å and for IILs 21.5Å) than that of CP-MS41 [68–73]. The decrease of pore size diameter is due to a combined effect of lowering of the surface area and pore volume for higher amounts of organic group incorporation. Really there is no reason for shrinking of the pore size during immobilization; hence the rate of diffusion of the reactant molecules may not be disturbed owing to immobilization. The CP 13C MAS-NMR results of CP-MS41 (4.5) show peaks at 50.2 (a′), 43.2 (b′), and 34.3 (c′)ppm corresponding to the carbon atoms of Cl–CH2 (a′), –CH2 (b′), and –CH2 (c′), respectively, as shown in Fig. 4 [74]. The CP 13C MAS-NMR of n-EImBr-MS41 (4.5) shows a variety of peaks in the range from 0 to 114ppm; total carbon values exactly match the theoretically calculated values. The immobilization of imidazole on host system was further confirmed from the appearance of aromatic imidazole peaks around 110–140ppm. The cis carbons of imidazole moieties are observed at the adjacent peaks of 114 and 117ppm. Solid-state 29Si MAS-NMR spectra of CP-MS41 (4.5) confirmed the presence of organo-functionalized moieties as a part of the silica wall structure for all the organically modified MCM-41 materials (Fig. 5 ). Distinct resonances can be clearly observed for the siloxane [Q n =Si(OSi) n (OH)4−n , n =2–4; Q3 at −104ppm; Q4 at −112ppm] and organosiloxane [T m =RSi(OSi) m (OH)3−m , m =1–3; T3 at −77ppm; T2 at −74ppm] units [75], whereas the post-grafting method shows T1 to be the only main peak compared with T2 and T3 [74]. The 29Si MAS-NMR of n-EImBr-MS41 shows some shielding effect compared to the parent CP-MS41, since the ionically connected host materials has less electron density due to a greater more number of aromatized imidazoles. Therefore, the resulting material shows much more shielded silica [Q3 at −121ppm, Q4 at −131ppm and T3 at −82ppm]. Fig. 6 shows the FT-IR spectra of the parent and grafted materials. The bands at 2969 and 2937cm−1 were assigned to alkyl –C–H stretching, whereas the bands at 3116 and 3018cm−1 were assigned to aromatic –C–H stretching vibrations. Comparatively weak bands appearing at approximately 1721, 1480, and 1420cm−1 were assigned to –C–H bending vibrations, originating from the –CH2 groups present in the organic silane group. The presence of the imidazole in the host system can be further evidenced by confirming the presence of the –C–N (for amine 1360–1020cm−1) stretching; however, the small peaks were observed at 1216cm−1 (Fig. 7 and curves a–d) for imidazolium units. The bands at 1045 and 769cm−1 [76,77] were attributed to the stretching and bending vibrations of the mesoporous framework (Si–O–Si). The –OH stretching region of CP-MS41 (4.5) between 3500 and 3000cm−1 was absent due to the hydrophobicity of the organosilane in the framework [78]. Conversely, the immobilized materials in Fig. 6 show a weak band at 3455cm−1. These strong stretching bands from the IILs were observed around the –OH region due to the physisorption of water, given the ionic nature of the –N+Br− bond in the ionic liquids. This also highlights the formation of –N+Br− groups in the functional materials. The effect of immobilization was demonstrated with EA, revealing the amount of imidazolium units present in the IILs (Table 2 ). CP-MS41 (4.5) showed trace amounts of nitrogen even after two iterations of acid leaching. The amount of RIm+X− units clearly showed that the effect of immobilization was independent of imidazole. All the n-EImBr-MS41, iso-PImBr-MS41, n-PImBr-MS41 and n-BImBr-MS41 show higher RIm+X− units, indicating that the small and flat-type five-membered cyclic imidazole immobilization was not interrupted due to the common initial stage immobilization step. 3.2 Insertion of carbon dioxide to AGE by substituted imidazole modified MS41 (RIm+X−-MS41) The immobilized RIm+X−-MS41 catalysts were tested for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate from AGE and carbon dioxide in a high-pressure batch reactor. Scheme 3 shows the general mechanism for the formation of cyclic carbonate through an intermediate using a catalyst for the reaction between the oxirane–carbon dioxide systems, as previously proposed [21,32,79–81]. It was reported that the rate-determination step is the attack at the anionic site of the catalyst, forming a bulky quaternary onium salt by the oxirane. The overall reaction is believed to consist of two steps: (i) a reversible reaction between the oxirane and IIL (QX) to form an intermediate complex and (ii) an irreversible reaction between the intermediate complex and carbon dioxide to form the cyclic carbonate and QX. The cycloaddition reaction of CO2 to AGE was carried out in the presence of the IILs. Table 3 shows AGE conversion, selectivity, and yield of AGC, and TON for different RIm+X−-MS41s under various reaction conditions. The AGE-conversion of n-EImBr-MS41, iso-PImBr-MS41, n-PImBr-MS41 and n-BImBr-MS41, was very high, close to 100% after 6h at 110°C and 1.76MPa of CO2. The n-BImBr-MS41 shows a higher level of AGE-conversion. This is not only due to the higher number of imidazolium units (0.293mmol/g), but also to the influence of the electron density, the high surface area of the host material, and the ease of formation of ionic interactions with the substrates, leading to chemisorption onto the active sites. Conversely, the TON results differ from the charge density, as the TON of n-BImBr-MS41 was not greater than iso-PImBr-MS41. This shows that AGE-conversion was influenced by various factors for the progress from the reaction mechanism. The previously reported Mg/Al oxide-based catalyst system required a high catalyst loading to substrate ratio (1.8g/g) [25], in addition to a substantial amount of solvent (85%, v/v DMF) and longer reaction times (24h). Silica-supported, guanidine catalysts also required longer reaction times (70h) and high pressures [82]. Microporous hybrid silica achieved the maximum conversion only by the addition of zinc chloride with the immobilized materials [50]. These microporous materials were unable to access the large-size reactants; therefore, such a reaction required the addition of an ionic salt. Hence, the reaction yielded the maximum outcome through the conversion of the catalyst from a heterogeneous to homogenous system. In contrast, the RIm+X−-MS41s gave the highest outcome, better than those of other heterogeneous, immobilized, ionic systems published thus far. In order to explain the advantage and importance of this study, the activity of the higher ionic-system (RIm+X−-MS41) was compared with the lower ionic-system (Hybrid Ti(Al)-SBA-15) developed by Srivastava et al., which contained a functional organic and Lewis acidic inorganic active system [51]. These organic–inorganic active systems satisfy the requirements but the system remains complicated. The substituted, imidazole-immobilized CP-MS41 showed better activity, potentially due to the high strength of ionic character generated and the well-separated imidazole group, through aromaticity, resulting in activity greater than the organic–inorganic active system [51]. Table 3 also shows the influence of reaction temperature on AGE-conversion and AGC yield. An examination of the reaction temperatures from 80 to 140°C (with CO2 pressure at 0.86MPa) revealed an increase in AGE-conversion, but a decrease in AGC selectivity, with an optimized AGC yield at 110°C. This clearly indicated that a lower temperature was not the optimum condition for the higher chemisorption of AGE on the IILs compared to the higher temperature that encourages preferential hydrolysis and allows the production of diols over AGC. The results of the pressure effect on the reaction are in good agreement with a two phase reaction mechanism. The AGE-conversion increased with increasing pressure. When the CO2 pressure was increased from 0.86 to 2.58MPa, the level of AGE-conversion increased up to 2.17MPa, but decreased with further increases in pressure. This was attributed to the increase in the availability of absorbed CO2 molecules in close proximity to the active sites with increasing pressure. This caused the facile engagement of molecules with the active sites through adsorption, resulting in an increase in activity. However, above the optimum pressure, high pressure can inhibit contact of the reactant molecules with the active sites due to a dilution effect, which decreases the activity. The higher length of the n-butane group present in the active center may give greater hindrance than other linear, alkyl groups from alkyl halides (1-bromoethane and 1-bromopropane). While comparing the higher and lower activities of the RIm+X−-MS41s, the activity depends on the diffusion limitation of residual pores, the n-BImBr-MS41, solid ions with lengthy n-butyl linker moieties in the channels may cause some diffusion limitations, whereas iso-PImBr-MS41 solid ions do not have large diffusion constraints, as in the previous case, even though the isopropyl linker moieties will show some influence through steric factors over the approaching bulky reactant oxiranes. However, the results demonstrate that the more steric isopropyl group shows lower AGE-conversion. Conversely, iso-PImBr-MS41 shows higher TON value than that of the material activated by n-butyl group (n-BImBr-MS41) that explains some of the other additional influence also playing a key role. This is more likely the steric hindrance for the reactants to approach the active sites can express interims of free-space-availability. This can be explained by the amount of imidazolium units per gram in iso-PImBr-MS41 being significantly lower than the n-BImBr-MS41 (Table 2); the lower imidazole units may result in a material with a higher average-idle-adjust space (Scheme 4 ). Such free space may support the approach of AGE and formation of the bulky intermediates without producing diffusion constraints, thus enhance the diffusion–adsorption–desorption rate of the reaction. The effect of solvent on the reactivity of n-EImBr-MS41 was also studied. Table 3 shows that the solvent-free reaction had activity superior to the solvent containing system, whereas selectivity showed a different trend, possibly attributable to the solvation of dichloromethane or acetonitrile, which would prevent the availability of CO2 near the active sites. Moreover, acetonitrile can coordinate with both CO2 and water, thus reducing the AGE-conversion and increasing the AGC selectivity. This activity can be explained from the TON of AGE-yield, which shows that the reaction falls on a typical heterogeneous reaction trend. If one compares the differences in CO2 pressure, the n-EImBr-MS41 catalyst shows a gradual increase in TON up to 2.17MPa, but a little decrease above the optimum pressure, indicating that the TON depends entirely on the availability of CO2. The second catalytic cycle was run to examine the stability of the catalytic activity and recycling. In each cycle, the catalyst was separated by filtration and used directly for the next run. Control experiments were performed to examine the extent of leaching, which could also account for loss of activity. The reaction conversion was either unaffected or insignificantly affected by the lack of leaching phenomenon in the consecutive cycles (n-EImBr-MS41 showed 98.4% AGE-conversion with 89.3% AGC selectivity at 1.76MPa after 6h at 110°C on a second cycle). Therefore, the formation of ionic bonds to the IILs and the porous system was unaffected by the reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions RIm+X−-MS41 materials were generated with a larger number of active sites, more uniform pores, higher surface area, better long-range order, and better-distributed functionality than the materials produced using the post-grafting technique. Moreover, these materials are reusable without affecting long-range order. The activity of these solid ions was not influenced significantly by high pressure, high temperature, or higher amounts of catalyst due to the presence of a larger number of active sites in the host system. However, the solvation effect of the catalyst had a negative influence on both conversion and selectivity. coredata.dc:description: Activation of chloropropyl MCM-41 (CP-MS41) and its utilization in the synthesis of allyl glycidyl carbonate over functionalized mesoporous MS41 solids has been investigated. The surface activity of MS41 was modified through consecutive immobilization of imidazole, followed by alkylation with an alkyl halide, resulting in the imidazole substituent-immobilized MS41 (RIm+X−-MS41 or IIL). A wide variety of CP-MS41 and RIm+X−-MS41 were synthesized and characterized using XRD, BET, elemental analysis (EA), SEM, CP13C, 29Si MAS-NMR, and FT-IR. EA and FT-IR confirmed adduct formation of ionic liquids with the chloropropyl groups on the host system. The efficiency of immobilization of activated materials was investigated by FT-IR and EA. RIm+X−-MS41 reacted further with oxiranes adsorbed on solid ions, forming cyclic carbonates. The IIL with a lower alkyl chain length and high electron-donating tendencies showed a higher level of reusability and superior activity. The CP-MS41 functionalized with isopropyl imidazolium bromide (iso-PImBr-MS41) exhibited the highest turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF).
coredata.dc:title: Functionalization of organic ions on hybrid MCM-41 for cycloaddition reaction: The effective conversion of carbon dioxide
